group.name: Sheet #2 - Experimental Sheet V2
group.description: Sheet to be bundled in lesson format

question.name: 2.1 Hydraulic Scale
question.text:
2.1 Hydraulic Scale

Guidance
This question, for starting ME2 students, is a deliberately easy refresher question to get you back into the swing of things.

A piston of diameter \(\mathrm{D = 0.1\,m}\) is fitted inside a U-shaped tube filled with liquid mercury (with \(\mathrm{density = 13,540\,kgm^{-3}}\)), as shown by the sketch below. The mercury rises by \(\mathrm{h = 1\,mm}\) under the weight of the piston.

  • (a)

  • (b)

What is the mass \(m\) of the piston?

<1>
  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions

At a given horizontal level in a static fluid with a free surface we know that the pressure must be constant. This means that the fluid under the piston must have a pressure equal to that beneath the raised height of mercury. We can write a force balance for the piston (including its weight, atmospheric pressure acting on its top surface, and the pressure under it), and for the raised column of mercury at the height of the piston's face. \(\begin{equation} mg + p_{atm}A_{piston} = pA_{piston}\hspace{0.5cm},\hspace{0.5cm}pA_{column} = (\rho g h + p_{atm})A_{column} \end{equation}\)

⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

We may combine these equations, cancelling out \(p\).

\(\begin{eqnarray} \frac{mg}{A_{piston}} + p_{atm} = &p& = \rho g h + p_{atm}\\ \frac{m}{\pi (\frac{ \mathrm{0.1} }{2})^2} &=& \rho h\\ m &=& \rho \pi h \left(\frac{\mathrm{0.1}}{2}\right)^2\\ m &=& \pi(\mathrm{13,540})(\mathrm{0.001})(\mathrm{0.05})^2\\ m &=& \mathrm{0.1063 kg} \end{eqnarray}\)

1.063 kg

1.063 kg

What would be the effect of increasing the diameter of the gauge-tube from 2 mm to 4 mm?

<2>
  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions

As the expression for pressure in the gauge-tube is not dependent on its cross-sectional area, the size of the tube makes causes no change to \(h\).

⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

We may combine these equations, cancelling out \(p\).

\(\begin{eqnarray} \frac{mg}{A_{piston}} + p_{atm} = &p& = \rho g h + p_{atm}\\ \frac{m}{\pi (\frac{ \mathrm{0.1} }{2})^2} &=& \rho h\\ m &=& \rho \pi h \left(\frac{\mathrm{0.1}}{2}\right)^2\\ m &=& \pi(\mathrm{13,540})(\mathrm{0.001})(\mathrm{0.05})^2\\ m &=& \mathrm{0.1063 kg} \end{eqnarray}\)

\(h\) remains the same

\(h\) remains the same

Comments

question.name: 2.2 Viscometer
question.text:
2.2 Viscometer

Guidance
This question from ME1 has been selected here to showcase some of the features of Mobius.

A long cylindrical rotor of length \(L\) and radius \(R\) rotates inside a cylindrical stator at a steady angular velocity \(\omega \). The small gap between the rotor has a uniform radial width \(d\) and contains a fluid with uniform viscosity \(\mu \), while the flow is incompressible and laminar.
Neglecting the curvature of the rotor and using cartesian coordinates, the differential equation describing the fluid motion is \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^2u}{\mathrm{d}y^2}=0\).

  • (a)

  • (b)

Find a simplified expression for the velocity profile, \(u(y)\), in terms of \(\omega\), \(R\), \(y\), and \(d\). Define \(y=0\) at the radius of the rotor.

\( u(y) = \)

<1>

How to input equations

The equation questions use Maple syntax to evaluate formulas. This is different from LaTeX in a couple of ways:

Like in Python, adding, subtracting, multiplying and dividing can be done using the symbols + - * /.

Remember to use an asterisk for multiplication, otherwise Maple will interpret it as one big variable!

For Greek letters, type the full name of the letter (e.g. 'mu' will render \( \mu \). unlike LaTeX, there is no need for slashes).

Click the omega Ω icon to preview your equation.

For example, writing G*M*m/(r^2) will produce:

\( \frac{G M m}{r^2} \)

  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions
  • Structured Tutorial
⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

\( \omega R \left(1 - \frac{y}{d}\right) \)

\( \omega R \left(1 - \frac{y}{d}\right) \)

Which of the following gives the correct expression for the magnitude of the power, \(P\), required to drive the rotor?

<2>
  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions
  • Structured Tutorial
⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

\(P = \frac{2\pi L\omega^2 R^3 \mu}{d}\)

\(P = \frac{2\pi L\omega^2 R^3 \mu}{d}\)

Comments

question.name: 2.3 Drag on a Plate
question.text:
2.3 Drag on a Plate

Guidance
This question requires only ME1 knowledge, and is a chance to refresh the technique of using control volumes. We will use this technique extensively throughout the year.

A fluid with density \(\mathrm{\rho = 800\,kgm^{-3}}\), flows at \(\mathrm{U_0 = 3\,ms^{-1}}\) over a flat plate of unit length and width. At the trailing edge the boundary-layer thickness is \(\mathrm{\delta = 25\,mm}\). Assume the velocity at the trailing edge to be linear (as shown in Fig. 1), and the flow to be two-dimensional.

  • (a)

  • (b)

Compute the mass flow rate across the top surface of the control volume (noted 'ab' in the image).

<1>
  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions
  • Structured Tutorial
⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

30 kg/s

30 kg/s

Determine the drag force on the plate.

<2>
  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions
  • Structured Tutorial
⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

30 N

30 N

Comments

question.name: 2.4 Small gravitational waves in shallow waters
question.text:
2.4 Small gravitational waves in shallow waters

Guidance
This question cultivates an analytical approach to problems. The separate parts provide adequate structure for the student to progress through the question, but the new type of analysis that is required is challenging for some students. The question relates to our life experience in the final parts, by quantifying the speed of a truck based purely on a photo. The more subtle part of this question is the relation between shallow water waves and compression waves. If you can see this analogy then you are starting to master your art!

Consider a long, horizontal, shallow, open channel containing a stationary liquid. A small disturbance is initiated at one end of the channel and raises the water level by a small amount (\(\mathrm{d}h\)). The disturbance moves with constant velocity \(c\)

  • (a)

  • (b)

  • (c)

  • (d)

  • (e)

  • (f)

  • (g)

  • (h)

Define a control volume in the reference frame moving with the compression front. Apply mass conservation and show that \(h\mathrm{d}u = c\mathrm{d}h - \mathrm{d}h\mathrm{d}u\).

  • Worked Solutions

Let us apply the mass-conservation principle to the control volume attached to the moving front (see sketch below). Note that what we've chosen is a control volume and not a material volume, meaning that by it's definition, we should be using the boundary velocity (i.e. the velocity of the control volume) and not the velocity of the fluid. However, if we assume that our chosen control volume is a material control volume which happens to perfectly coincide with the fixed control volume at \( t=t_{\small 0} \), then we may use the velocity of the fluid, and not that of the boundary.

⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

If we consider the control volume as a moving reference, i.e. subtract \( c \) from all sides, then we are left with the velocities in the above sketch.

We can now apply the Reynolds transport theorem:

\( \Large{\int}_{\small \mathrm{cv}}\normalsize{\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}\mathrm{d}V} +\Large{\oint}_{\small \mathrm{cs}}\normalsize{\rho\left(\vec{u}\cdot\vec{n}\right)\space\mathrm{d}A} \)

The fluid's density is assumed to be constant (fair assumption for water at same temperature with no salinity). The above equation then simplifies to:

\( 0=\Large{\oint}_{\small \mathrm{cs}}\normalsize{\vec{u}\cdot\vec{n}\space \mathrm{d}A} = \Large{\int}_{\small{\enclose{circle}{1}}}\normalsize{\vec{u}\cdot\vec{n}\space\mathrm{d}A} +\Large{\int}_{\small{\enclose{circle}{2}}}\normalsize{\vec{u}\cdot\vec{n}\space\mathrm{d}A} \)

where we used the fact that \( \vec{u}\cdot\vec{n} =0\) for both the top \( \enclose{circle}{3} \)and bottom \( \enclose{circle}{4} \) surfaces. Hence:

\( 0=\Large{\int}_{\small \enclose{circle}{1}}\normalsize{ \begin{bmatrix} -c \\ ? \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\cdot \begin{bmatrix} 1\\0\\0 \end{bmatrix} }\mathrm{d}A + \Large{\int}_{\small \enclose{circle}{2}}\normalsize{ \begin{bmatrix} \mathrm{d}u-c\\?\\0 \end{bmatrix}\cdot \begin{bmatrix} -1\\0\\0 \end{bmatrix}\mathrm{d}A= -W\Large{\int}_{\small y=0}^{\small h}\normalsize{c\space\mathrm{d}y} } -W\Large{\int}_{\small y=0}^{\small h+\mathrm{d}h}\normalsize{(\mathrm{d}u-c)\space \mathrm{d}y} \)

where \( W \) is the width of the control volume. Dividing by \( W \) and noting that neither \( c \) nor \( \mathrm{d}u \) are taken to be functions of \( y \) we find:

\( 0=-ch-(h+\mathrm{d}h)(\mathrm{d}u-c)\longrightarrow ch=-h\space \mathrm{d}u+ch-\mathrm{d}h\space\mathrm{d}u+c\space \mathrm{d}h \longrightarrow h\space \mathrm{d}u=c\space \mathrm{d}h-\mathrm{d}h\space\mathrm{d}u \)

Assuming that \(\varepsilon\equiv\mathrm{d} h / h \ll 1\), show that \(c\,\mathrm{d}h = h\,\mathrm{d} u + \mathcal{O}(c h \varepsilon^2)\)

  • Worked Solutions

From \( h\space \mathrm{d}u=c\space \mathrm{d}h-\mathrm{d}h\space\mathrm{d}u \), we can divide by \(ch\) to arrive at the following:

⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

\( \frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c}=\frac{\mathrm{d}h}{h}-\frac{\mathrm{d}h}{h}\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c} \)

From the question description, we know that \( \varepsilon \equiv \mathrm{d}h/h \ll1 \), so we can therefore say that:

\(\varepsilon \sim \frac{\mathrm{d}h}{h}\) (i.e. the two terms are of the same order).

Likewise, since we known that \( \mathrm{d}u \) is much smaller than \(c\) (because it's a small disturbance), we can say the following: \(\mathrm{d}u\ll c \longrightarrow \frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c}\ll 1 \space\space\space\therefore \space \space \frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c}\sim \varepsilon \)

Now that we know both terms are of order \( \varepsilon \), we can use order of magnitude analysis to simplify the above equation:

\( \underset{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)}{\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c}}=\underset{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)}{\frac{\mathrm{d}h}{h}}-\underset{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)}{\frac{\mathrm{d}h}{h}}\underset{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)}{\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c}} \)

Therefore:

\( \underset{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)}{\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c}}=\underset{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)}{\frac{\mathrm{d}h}{h}}-\underset{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^2)}{\frac{\mathrm{d}h}{h}{\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c}}} \)

To the first order in \( \varepsilon \ll 1 \) we find that:

\( {\frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c}}={\frac{\mathrm{d}h}{h}}-\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^2)\)

Multiplying by \(ch\), we get:

\( c\,\mathrm{d}h = h\,\mathrm{d}u + \mathcal{O}(ch\varepsilon^2)\)

Apply Bernoulli's equation along the water surface (which is a streamline at constant pressure) to find that \(g\,\mathrm{d} h = c\,\mathrm{d} u + \mathcal{O}(c^2\varepsilon^2)\).

  • Worked Solutions

The free surface is a streamline. The flow being considered steady and the fluid being assumed inviscid with constant density, we apply Bernoulli’s equation along \( \enclose{circle}{3} \):

⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

\( p+\frac{1}{2}\rho U^2+\rho gz=C \longrightarrow \begin{cases} \mathrm{at}\space \enclose{circle}{3}\cap\enclose{circle}{1} & p_{at} &+& \rho c^2/2 & +&\rho gh &= &C \\ \mathrm{at}\space \enclose{circle}{3}\cap\enclose{circle}{2} & p_{at} &+& \rho (\mathrm{d}u-c)^2/2 & +&\rho g(h+\mathrm{d}h) &= &C \end{cases} \)

Subtracting the first line from the second one in the above system gives:

\( \frac{1}{2}\rho \mathrm{d}u^2-\rho c \mathrm{d}u+\rho g\mathrm{d}h=0 \)

Diving by \( \rho c^2 \) and considering the orders of the terms:

\( \underbrace{ \frac{1}{2}\left ( \frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c} \right)^2}_{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon^2)} -\underbrace{ \frac{\mathrm{d}u}{c} }_{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)} +\underbrace{ \frac{g}{c^2}\mathrm{d}h }_{\mathcal{O}(\varepsilon)} \)

Therefore, to the first order of \( \varepsilon \):

\( g\mathrm{d}h=c\space \mathrm{d}h+\mathcal{O(c^2\varepsilon^2)}\)

Find an expression for \(c\).

\( c = \)

<1>

How to input equations

The equation questions use Maple syntax to evaluate formulas. This is different from LaTeX in a couple of ways:

Like in Python, adding, subtracting, multiplying and dividing can be done using the symbols + - * /.

Remember to use an asterisk for multiplication, otherwise Maple will interpret it as one big variable!

For Greek letters, type the full name of the letter (e.g. 'mu' will render \( \mu \). unlike LaTeX, there is no need for slashes).

Click the omega Ω icon to preview your equation.

For example, writing G*M*m/(r^2) will produce:

\( \frac{G M m}{r^2} \)

  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions

From (a) \(\times c/h\), and (b):

⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

\( \begin{cases} c\>\mathrm{d}u &=& \left(c^2/h\right )\mathrm{d}h &+ & \mathcal{O\left (c^2\varepsilon^2\right)} \\ g\>\mathrm{d}h &=& \space\space \space\space\space\space c\>\mathrm{d}h &+ & \mathcal{O\left (c^2\varepsilon^2\right)} \end{cases} \longrightarrow \space c^2=gh \longrightarrow \) therefore:

\(\boxed{c=\sqrt{gh}\space}\)

A truck travels through shallow water at some speed \(U\). The ratio of \(U\) with \(c\) is known as the Froude number (noted \(\mathrm{Fr}\))
Sketch the wave pattern for \(\mathrm{Fr} > 1\). Show that a Mach cone must form.

  • Worked Solutions

The wave pattern for \( \mathrm{Fr}>1 \) is:

A truck travels through shallow water at some speed \(U\). The ratio of \(U\) with \(c\) is known as the Froude number (noted \(\mathrm{Fr}\))
Find a relationship between the Froude number and the Mach cone angle.

  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions

Based on the sketch above, \( \sin(\theta)=c\tau/U\tau=c/U=1/\mathrm{Fr} \)

\( \boxed{\theta=\sin^{-1}\left(\frac{1}{\mathrm{Fr}}\right)} \)

A truck travels through shallow water at some speed \(U\). The ratio of \(U\) with \(c\) is known as the Froude number (noted \(\mathrm{Fr}\))
Estimate the speed of the truck in the picture below (state your assumptions).

<2>
  • Show Answer
  • Worked Solutions
⬆ Previous Step ⬆
⬇ Next Step ⬇
Show All

Reading from the picture:

\( \tan(\theta)\approx\frac{7.5}{18}\longrightarrow \theta \approx 23^{\circ} \)

The Froude number is \( \mathrm{Fr}=1/\sin(\theta) \approx 2.6 \). Assuming the water level to be around \( 30 \space \mathrm{cm} \) and taking \( g=9.8 \space \mathrm{m/s^2} \) we have:

\( U=c\mathrm{Fr}=\mathrm{Fr}\sqrt{gh}\)

\(U\approx \boxed{16 \space \mathrm{km/h}}\)

A truck travels through shallow water at some speed \(U\). The ratio of \(U\) with \(c\) is known as the Froude number (noted \(\mathrm{Fr}\))
Suppose that the bottom wall is slightly rising in the wave direction. Based on your analysis for the horizontal wall, explain why you expect the wave front to steepen. Relate this finding to your observation of breaking waves on the beach.

  • Worked Solutions

If the bottom wall is rising with \(x\), then \(h(x)\) is decreasing. Consequently, \( c=\sqrt{gh} \) would be reducing. This means that compression waves from downstream would be catching up with the ones further upstream (since they travel at reduced speeds). This in turn suggests that the compression waves 'accumulate' as the water level decreases, contributing to the steepening of the compression front which eventually forms a breaking wave.

Comments
